The eight kinds of mastery, what are they?

Answer: Internally having the notion of form, observing external forms as few, whether beautiful or ugly, having such a thought of those forms, knowing and seeing them as superior, this is the first kind of mastery.

Internally having the notion of form, observing external forms as many, whether beautiful or ugly, having such a thought of those forms, knowing and seeing them as superior, this is the second kind of mastery.

Internally without the notion of form, observing external forms as few, whether beautiful or ugly, having such a thought of those forms, knowing and seeing them as superior, this is the third kind of mastery.

Internally without the notion of form, observing external forms as many, whether beautiful or ugly, having such a thought of those forms, knowing and seeing them as superior, this is the fourth kind of mastery.

Internally without form-perceptions, observing external forms, either blue, of blue color, of blue luster; just like a flax flower, or just like fine Benares muslin, which is blue, of blue color, of blue luster.
Internally without form-perceptions, observing external forms, either blue, of blue color, of blue luster, just like this, one has such knowledge and such vision. This is the fifth sphere of mastery.

Internally without form-perceptions, observing external forms, either yellow, of yellow color, of yellow luster; just like a kannikara flower, or just like fine Benares muslin, which is yellow, of yellow color, of yellow luster.

Internally without form-perceptions, observing external forms, either yellow, of yellow color, of yellow luster, just like this, one has such knowledge and such vision. This is the sixth sphere of mastery.

Internally without form-perceptions, one observes external forms as red, red in color, red in appearance, red in luster. Like the bandhu-jÄ«vaka flower, or like fine BÄrÄá¹‡asÄ« cloth, which is red, red in color, red in appearance, red in luster.

Internally without form-perceptions, one observes external forms as red, red in color, red in appearance, red in luster, in the same way. One has such perceptions regarding those forms, this is the seventh sphere of mastery.

Internally without form-perceptions, one observes external forms as white, white in color, white in appearance, white in luster. Like the color of the Utpala star, or like fine BÄrÄá¹‡asÄ« cloth, which is white, white in color, white in appearance, white in luster.

Internally without form-perceptions, one observes external forms as white, white in color, white in appearance, white in luster, in the same way. One has such perceptions regarding those forms, this is the eighth sphere of mastery.

Having internal form perception means that regarding internal distinct form perceptions, one has not yet abandoned them, has not yet separated from them, has not yet subdued them, has not yet controlled them, has not yet destroyed them, has not yet broken them. Because one has not yet abandoned them, has not yet separated from them, has not yet subdued them, has not yet controlled them, has not yet destroyed them, has not yet broken them, it is called having internal form perception.
Observing external forms as small means that the forms being observed are extremely small in quantity, subtle and not many, and for that reason they are called small.
If good means that the forms being observed have already been well polished and are blue, yellow, red, and white, and for that reason they are called if good.
If bad means that the forms being observed have not yet been well polished and are blue, yellow, red, and white, and for that reason they are called if bad.

Superior knowledge and superior vision regarding those forms means that regarding those forms being observed, one has already subdued desire and greed, has already severed desire and greed, has already transcended desire and greed, and regarding them one has already attained superior knowledge and superior vision, has subdued and mastered them, and is completely fearless.
It is like a noble person or the noble son, using superior knowledge and insight to control and subdue servants, with complete mastery and fearlessness.

The yogis are also like this. Having already subdued desire and greed for the observed form, having already eliminated desire and greed, having already transcended desire and greed, they have attained superior knowledge and insight, with mastery and fearlessness.
There is such a thought, referring to the thought of suchness that is presently manifest.
First means that among all concentrations, it is counted as the first in sequential order.
The sphere of mastery means the wholesome form, feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness in this concentration, all of which are called the sphere of mastery.
Internally without form perception, observing external forms as numerous, etc. means that the observed form is vast and boundless, hence called numerous.
The rest is explained as before.

As for 'no internal form conception', it means that regarding internal distinct form conceptions, one has already abandoned them, already separately abandoned them, already subdued them, already separately subdued them, already destroyed them, and already broken them apart.

Because one has already abandoned internal distinct form conceptions, already separately abandoned them, already subdued them, already separately subdued them, already destroyed them, and already broken them apart, it is called 'no internal form conception'.
Observing external forms as small or large, etc., is all as explained above.
As for 'internally without form conception, observing external forms as blue', it generally indicates all blue forms, blue aggregates, and blue masses, thus it is said 'as blue'.
'Blue appearance' means this blue form is appearance, not shape, thus it is said 'blue appearance'.
'Blue manifestation' means this blue form is the domain of activity of eye consciousness, and also the domain of activity of mental consciousness, thus it is said 'blue manifestation'.
'Blue radiance' means this blue form can manifest and emit various lights, thus it is said 'blue radiance'.
The rest is explained as before.
As it is said for blue, etc., it is the same for yellow, etc.
Chapter 10: The Nine Dharmas At that time, ÅšÄriputra again said to the assembly:
Venerable ones, you should know that the Buddha himself has thoroughly understood and realized nine dharmas, and has proclaimed and revealed them to his disciples.

We should now gather together to compile them, so that there will be no disputes after the Buddha's parinirvÄá¹‡a. We should cause the Dharma and Vinaya to abide for a long time, benefiting immeasurable beings, having compassion for the heavenly and human beings in the world, enabling them to attain supreme benefits and happiness.
What are the nine dharmas?
In brief, there are two kinds of nine dharmas, namely the nine knots and the nine abodes of sentient beings.
What are the nine knots?
Answer:
First, the knot of craving;
second, the knot of anger;
third, the knot of pride;
fourth, the knot of ignorance;
fifth, the knot of views;
sixth, the knot of grasping;
Seventh, the knot of doubt;
Eighth, the knot of jealousy;
Ninth, the knot of stinginess.
What is the knot of craving?
Answer:
Greed in the three realms is called the knot of craving.
What is the knot of hatred?
Answer:

Desiring to harm sentient beings, harboring malice within, wanting to disturb and agitate, having already been angry, being about to be angry, and being angry in the present, delighting in harm and extreme harm, with a mind of utmost resentment, wanting to cause harm by opposing sentient beings, having already caused harm, being about to cause harm, and currently causing harm, this is called the knot of hatred.
What is the knot of conceit?
Answer:
The seven types of conceit are called the knot of conceit.
What are the seven?
Answer:
First, conceit;
Second, over-conceit;
Third, conceit over conceit;
Fourth, conceit of self;
Fifth, conceit of superiority;
Sixth, conceit of inferiority;
Seventh, false conceit.
These seven types of conceit are combined into the knot of conceit.
What is the fetter of ignorance?
Answer:
Lack of knowledge in the three realms is called the fetter of ignorance.
What is the fetter of views?
Answer:
Three kinds of views are called the fetter of views.
What are the three?
Answer:
First, the view of a real self;
second, the view of extremes;
third, wrong views.
These three views together are called the fetter of views.
What is the fetter of grasping?
Answer:ğŸ”½Two kinds of grasping are called the fetter of grasping.
What are the two?
Answer:
First, grasping at views;
second, grasping at precepts and practices.
These two kinds of grasping together are called the fetter of grasping.
What is the fetter of doubt?
Answer:
Hesitation regarding the truths is called the fetter of doubt.
What is the fetter of jealousy?
Answer:
The mind not being able to bear it is called the fetter of jealousy.
What is the fetter of stinginess?
Answer:
The mind having secrecy and stinginess is called the fetter of stinginess.
As for the nine abodes of sentient beings, what are the nine?
Answer:
Sentient beings with form, with various bodies and various perceptions, such as humans and some gods, are the first abode of sentient beings.
Sentient beings with form, with various bodies but one kind of perception, such as the BrahmakÄyika gods at the beginning of the eon, are the second abode of sentient beings.
Sentient beings with form, with one kind of body but various perceptions, such as the Ä€bhÄsvara gods, are the third abode of sentient beings.
Sentient beings with form, with one kind of body and one kind of perception, such as the Åšubhaká¹›tsna gods, are the fourth abode of sentient beings.
Sentient beings with form, without perception or distinct perception, such as the Asaá¹ƒjÃ±isattvas, are the fifth abode of sentient beings.

Formless sentient beings, transcending all perceptions of form, eliminating perceptions of obstruction, not thinking of various perceptions, entering the sphere of infinite space, abiding in the perfection of the sphere of infinite space, like the Ä€kÄÅ›ÄnantyÄyatana gods, are the sixth abode of sentient beings.

Formless sentient beings, transcending all the sphere of infinite space, enter the sphere of infinite consciousness, abiding in fullness, like the gods of the sphere of infinite consciousness, this is the seventh abode of sentient beings.ğŸ”½Formless sentient beings, transcending all the sphere of infinite consciousness, enter the sphere of nothingness, abiding in fullness, like the gods of the sphere of nothingness, this is the eighth abode of sentient beings.

Formless sentient beings, transcending all the sphere of nothingness, enter the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, abiding in fullness, like the gods of the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, this is the ninth abode of sentient beings.

Here, those with form means those sentient beings who have the designation of form, have a form body, have a form location, have a form realm, and have a form aggregate, therefore they are called those with form.

Sentient beings means that although in the ultimate truth no sentient beings can be obtained, they are non-existent and not presently existent, yet based on the aggregates, elements, and sense bases, sentient beings are provisionally established. Various conceptual thoughts, equal conceptual thoughts, designations, and expressions are used, such as sentient beings, persons, mind-born, young men, life-possessors, born ones, nourished ones, human beings, and pudgalas. Therefore, it is called sentient beings.

Various bodies means that those sentient beings have various colored bodies, various characteristics, and various forms. They are not of one color, not of one characteristic, and not of one form. Therefore, it is called various bodies.

Various conceptual thoughts means that those sentient beings have the conceptual thought of happiness, the conceptual thought of suffering, and the conceptual thought of neither happiness nor suffering. Therefore, it is called various conceptual thoughts.
Like humans and some gods means that it comprehensively displays humans and the gods of the desire realm. Therefore, it is called like humans and some gods.
It is the first in the sense of being first in sequence.

The abodes of sentient beings refer to the places where sentient beings dwell, rely on, abide in, and enjoy being born. These are the contaminated aggregates of form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness.
Sentient beings with form have various bodies means the same as before.

One kind of ideation refers to when sentient beings, at a certain time and in a certain situation, go to be born in the common destiny of the higher heavens such as Ä€bhÄsvara when the world is about to be destroyed.
There, they fully possess a mind-made form body, with faculties complete and limbs perfect, with a clear appearance, long-lived and abiding for a long time.
At a certain time and in a certain situation, when the world is first formed, there suddenly appear empty palaces in the lower sky.

There is a sentient being whose lifespan, karma, and blessings are exhausted, who passes away from that realm and is reborn in the empty palace of the lower Brahma world, alone without companions, living a long life for a long time.
When that sentient being has lived for a long time, he suddenly gives rise to desire and unhappiness, and thinks like this:
How can I cause other sentient beings to be born in my class and be my companions?

When that sentient being gives rise to this wish in his mind, there are other sentient beings whose lifespans, karma, and blessings are exhausted, who again pass away from there and are reborn in the Brahma palace below, becoming companions with the previous sentient beings.
At that time, the one who was born earlier thinks like this:
This class of sentient beings is created by me.
I am the sovereign, the creator, the transformer, the giver of life, the progenitor of this class and the rest of the world, the true ancestor.
At that time, the sentient beings also think like this:
We sentient beings are created by him.
They are the masters, creators, transformers, givers of life, and progenitors of sentient beings and worldly things.
Therefore, it is called one thought.
As for the BrahmakÄyika gods, it generally refers to those born in the BrahmakÄyika and other heavens who have various bodies but only one thought.
The beginning of the eon means when the eon first began.
This is the second and so on, the meaning is as explained above.
Sentient beings with form means as explained above.

Having one kind of body means that those sentient beings have one apparent color body, one characteristic, and one shape, without various apparent colors, without various characteristics, and without various shapes, therefore it is called having one kind of body.
Having various thoughts means that those sentient beings have thoughts of happiness and neither suffering nor happiness, therefore it is called having various thoughts.
The rest is as explained above.
Sentient beings with form having one kind of body is also as explained above.
As for the thought of one kind, it means that those sentient beings have only the thought of pleasure, and therefore it is called the thought of one kind.
The rest is as explained above.
As for sentient beings with form, it is also as explained above.
As for the word without thought, it generally shows the absence of thought.
As for without a separate thought, it specifically shows the absence of thought.
Here, using thought as the foremost, it shows the absence of all mental factors.
As for the sentient beings without thought in the heavens, it specifically shows the sentient beings without thought in the heavens.
This is the fifth and so on, the meaning is as explained above.
As for the formless, it means that those sentient beings have no designation of form, no form body, no place of form, no realm of form, and no aggregate of form, and therefore it is called formless.
As for sentient beings, it is as explained above.
As for transcending all notions of form and so on, it is explained in detail in the Eight Liberations.
However, here, only the contaminated feelings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness are taken as the abodes of sentient beings.

Question:ğŸ”½What is the practice of the concentration of the universal sphere of earth?
By what means can practitioners realize and enter the concentration of the universal sphere of earth?
Answer:

For beginners who are newly practicing contemplation, they should not think of the various places on this great earth, whether high or low, with thorns or stumps, salty or thorny, dangerous or filthy, and so on.

In this great earth, in each and every place, the level and obvious [ground] is just like the palm of the hand. Take any one of the endowed and pure gardens and forests, which are delightful places, and with the power of resolve, fix the mind on it, contemplate it with imagination, observe it, and establish and believe that this is the characteristic of earth.

Because he fixes the mind on this with the power of resolve, contemplates it with imagination, observes it, establishes and believes that this is the characteristic of earth, the mind then becomes scattered and agitated, running to various characteristics, unable to direct itself and fixate on a single object, contemplating that this object is earth and not anything else.

Because his mind is scattered and agitated, running to various characteristics, unable to direct itself and fixate on a single object, contemplating that this object is definitely earth, he is still unable to penetrate the universal concentration on earth.
In order to gather in the scattered and agitated mind, he fixes the mind on the characteristic of earth and contemplates it, thinking this is earth and not water, etc.

Contemplating this characteristic with diligent and vigorous effort, he continues in this way until the mind abides for a long time. Through this practice, he is able to enter the concentration on earth.

Having diligently cultivated this preparatory practice many times, one further advances in practicing the expedient means of this samÄdhi, that is, repeatedly cultivating and repeatedly practicing the path induced by the preparatory practice, doing it many times.

Having repeatedly cultivated and repeatedly practiced the path induced by the preparatory practice, doing it many times, the mind then abides in equipoise, closely abiding, continuing in a single direction, and single-mindedly contemplates this object as definitely the characteristic of earth.

By the mind abiding in equipoise, closely abiding, continuing in a single direction, and single-mindedly contemplating this object as definitely the characteristic of earth, without duality or change, one is able to enter the earth samÄdhi, but one is still unable to enter the universal samÄdhi of earth.

In order to gather in the scattered and agitated mind, one fixes one's attention on the characteristic of universal earth and contemplates that this is universally earth, not universally water, etc.

Contemplating this characteristic with courageous and diligent effort, one causes the mind to continue for a long time. Through this practice, one is gradually able to enter the universal earth concentration.

Having cultivated this preparatory practice with effort and frequently, he further advances in cultivating the expedient of this samÄdhi, that is, he frequently cultivates and frequently practices the path induced by the preparatory practice.

Having frequently cultivated and frequently practiced the path induced by the preparatory practice, his mind then abides in equipoise, closely abides, continues in one direction, and focuses on one object, contemplating that this object is entirely earth.

By the mind abiding in equipoise, closely abiding, continuing in one direction, and focusing on one object, contemplating that this object is entirely earth, without duality and without turning away, he then enters the earth universal sphere samÄdhi.

the appearance of flames, or the appearance of a great flame burning wood for fifty years, or the appearance of a great flame burning wood forğŸ”½a hundred years, or the appearance of a great flame burning wood for a thousand years, or

Because their mind is scattered and flowing to various characteristics, unable to direct and fixate the mind on a single object, contemplating this object as being entirely fire, they are unable to penetrate and enter the concentration on the totality field of fire.
In order to gather in the scattered and flowing mind, they fixate their attention on the characteristic of pervading fire and contemplate, This is pervasively fire, not pervasively water, etc.

Contemplating this characteristic with diligent and vigorous effort, they cause the mind to continue for a long time. Due to this practice, they are then gradually able to enter the concentration on the totality field of fire.

Having diligently and repeatedly practiced this practice, they further progress in cultivating the expedient means for this concentration, namely, on the path induced by the practice, they repeatedly cultivate and repeatedly practice, doing so many times.

When you have repeatedly cultivated and repeatedly practiced the path induced by the preparatory stage, and have done so many times, the mind then abides in stability, near-stability, and continuous stability, and with attention focused on a single object, you contemplate this object as all being fire.

Because the mind abides in stability, near-stability, and continuous stability, and with attention focused on a single object, you contemplate this object as all being fire, without duality and without transition, you then enter the fire universal concentration.
As for above and below, this refers to the upper and lower directions.
As for extending sideways, this refers to the southeast and so on.
As for without duality, this means without admixture.
As for boundless and limitless, this means the limits are difficult to discern.
As for being the third, this means among the various concentrations, in sequential order, it is counted as the third.
As for universal, this refers to the wholesome form, feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness in this concentration, all of which are called universal.
Question: What is the practice for the wind universal concentration?
By what means can a practitioner of meditation realize and enter the wind universal sphere samÄdhi?

When a beginner first cultivates meditation, in this world they either take the characteristics of wind in the east, or take the characteristics of wind in the south, or take the characteristics of wind in the west, or take the characteristics of wind in the north, or take the characteristics of dusty wind, or take the characteristics of dustless wind, or take the characteristics of vaiÅ›vÄnara wind, or take the characteristics of vÄyu wind, or take the characteristics of small wind, or take the characteristics of great wind, or take the characteristics of immeasurable wind, or take the characteristics of the great wind-wheel.

From among these, they take any one characteristic, and by the power of resolve they fix their attention on it, imagine it, observe it, establish it, and believe it to be the characteristic of such-and-such a wind.

Because they, with regard to this, by the power of resolve, fix their thoughts, imagine, contemplate, and establish belief that this is a certain wind, the mind then becomes scattered and distracted, flowing to various characteristics, unable to direct and fixate the mind on a single object, contemplating this object as wind and not other.

Because their minds are scattered and distracted, flowing to various characteristics, unable to direct and fixate the mind on a single object, contemplating this object as definitely wind, they are unable to realize and enter the wind universal sphere samÄdhi.
In order to gather in the scattered and distracted mind, they fixate their thoughts on a single wind characteristic, thinking this is wind, not fire, etc.
Contemplating this characteristic, they exert vigor and effort, and so forth, causing the mind to continue for a long time. By this practice, they are able to enter the wind samÄdhi.

Having diligently and repeatedly practiced this practice, they further progress in cultivating the expedient means of this samÄdhi, that is, on the path induced by the practice, they repeatedly practice and repeatedly cultivate, doing much of it.

Having repeatedly cultivated and repeatedly practiced the path induced by preparatory effort, the mind then abides in equipoise, closely abides, and continues in one direction, fixing the mind on one object, contemplating this object as definitely having the characteristic of wind.

By the mind abiding in equipoise, closely abiding, and continuing in one direction, fixing the mind on one object, contemplating this object as definitely having the characteristic of wind, without duality and without turning back, one is able to enter the wind concentration, but is not yet able to enter the wind universal concentration.
